The stable and ultrathin hydrotalcite nanosheets with thickness of ca. 1.0 nm have been built on the surface of Al2O3 by sharing Al element and using layer growth inhibitor formamide. Based on the topological transformation characteristics of hydrotalcite and the structural memory effect of calcined product, the supported PtIn bimetallic catalyst was achieved by stepwise incipient wetness impregnation method followed by calcination and reduction, and evaluated in isobutane direct dehydrogenation (IDH) to isobutene. The derived ultrathin bimetallic catalyst possesses excellent IDH activity under extreme conditions, in which the isobutane conversion and isobutene selectivity can remain above 63% and 92% respectively, and the turnover frequency is as high as 13.45 s−1. The excellent activity can be attributed to the formation of ultrathin hydrotalcite precursor, which can greatly enhance the specific surface area, interaction among metal components, surface acidity of weak- and medium-acid sites and surface In3+/In0 ratio, and further effectively inhibit carbon deposition and improve dispersion and stability of active Pt species in the corresponding derivative. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Isobutane dehydrogenation Bimetallic catalysts Ultrathin nanosheets Formamide Pt dispersion Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Isobutene is an important chemical raw material for the production of methyl methacrylate (MMA), methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE), isoprene, polyisobutene, butyl rubber and other chemicals [1–4]. With the rapid development of industry, the existing production capacity of isobutene has been unable to meet the growing demand [1–3]. Besides the stream cracking and fluid catalytic cracking units, the isobutane direct dehydrogenation (IDH) to isobutene is another competitive process to produce the high value-added isobutene from the cheap and readily available isobutane [3,4]. The metal Pt species are known as the most effective active sites for the dehydrogenation of light alkanes [1,3–5]. Under high temperature reaction conditions, it is inevitable for the active Pt sintering and carbon deposition, which are the main reasons for Pt-based catalysts deactivation [3–6]. Usually, some additives such as Sn [1,3–6], In [3,7–11], Ga [12], Cu [13], Zn [14–16] and K [1,17] are used to improve the dehydrogenation performance and stability of these catalysts through geometric and electronic interactions with Pt species. Among them, the effect of In additive is similar to that of Sn additive [11]. On the one hand, the In species can be well distributed around Pt species, and effectively preventing the aggregation of Pt species and the formation of coke during the reaction process. On the other hand, the In species can increase the electron density around Pt species, weaken the adsorption between Pt and products, and thus inhibit the occurrence of side reactions [7]. In addition, compared to Pt-Sn catalysts, Pt-In catalysts have less dependence on the preparation process and are more suitable for dehydrogenation reactions [10]. It is noteworthy that a suitable In3+/In0 ratio can enhance the In-support interaction and stabilize the oxidized In species, while a large fraction of In0 species can block the Pt active sites, which may be a poison to the dehydrogenation reaction [11,18]. Modifying the support is also a commonly used method to improve the dehydrogenation performance of Pt-based catalysts. The high surface acidity of traditional Al2O3 supports can lead to side reactions such as coking and cracking, leading to catalyst deactivation. Alkali species, such as MgO, are usually added to reduce their surface acid sites [5,8,19]. It is worth emphasizing that the calcined hydrotalcite (HT) or HT-like materials have attracted extensive attention as layered supports of Pt-based catalysts for alkane dehydrogenation due to their suitable surface area, special lattice confinement and topological transformation, adjustable morphology and surface acidity [5,9,11]. Improving the dispersion and utilization of active components through support modification to improve isobutane conversion and isobutene selectivity can reduce the generation of by-products and environmental damage, which is also one of the development directions of molecular catalysis for the chemistry in the future [20]. It has been reported that the noble-based catalysts with ultrathin structure could improve the catalytic performance in many fields under mild conditions, due to possess the maximum accessible surface for reactants and expose abundant low-coordinated active species on the surface [21,22]. Ultrathin HT derived nanosheets have been deemed as appropriate templates to obtain the ultrathin noble-based catalysts [21,22]. They are also investigated in the fields of photocatalysis [23,24], electrocatalysis [25], adsorption [26], biomedicine [27] and so on. However, the ultrathin brucite-like nanosheets easily stack together arising from the strong van der Waals forces, hydrogen bonds and electrostatic interaction between the layers and the intercalated anions [28]. Although, there are many methods to obtain ultrathin HT nanosheets, involving top-down exfoliation method [29], bottom-up reverse microemulsion method [25], one-step synthesis method [30–32] and nucleation-crystallization isolation method [24]. It is still a challenge to avoid the re-stacking of lamellar structure and maintain the monolayer state [21,33]. In this context, the main aim of this work is to synthesize a stable and efficient PtIn bimetallic catalyst for IDH. For this purpose, the ultrathin HT-based nanosheets were designed as templates and in-situ grown on Al2O3 by sharing single Al element and forming in growth inhibitor formamide. The structure, texture and physicochemical properties of as-synthesized ultrathin HT nanosheets and its supported PtIn bimetallic catalyst were characterized by many methods and compared with those of reference sample prepared under the absence of formamide. The activity, selectivity and stability of IDH to isobutene were evaluated and the structure-properties relationship was investigated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The deionized water and analytical grade reagents, including H2PtCl6·6H2O, InNO3·xH2O, Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O, NaNO3, formamide and urea were used in the preparation processes of catalysts. 2.2 Preparation of alumina support The rod alumina support, labeled as Al-rod, was synthesized by hydrothermal method, and detail process was described in our previous report [34]. 2.3 Synthesis of supported HT precursors with and without formamide The Al-rod supported HT ultrathin precursor was synthesized by in-situ growth strategy under the protection of nitrogen. First, 3 g Al-rod powder was impregnated in a solution of 100.0 mL Mg(NO3)2 (0.150 M) under vacuum for 1 h. Then, 100.0 mL of 0.010 M NaNO3 solution containing and 50 vol% growth inhibitor formamide was thoroughly mixed with the above solution under magnetic stirring at 80 °C. After that, 0.50 M NaOH solution was dropped into the mixture to adjust pH value to ca. 10. The obtained slurry was aged at room temperature in air for 12 h and subsequently rinsed with ethanol and deionized water for 3 times respectively. Finally, the wet sample was dried overnight at 60 °C and solid product was named as HT-U. A reference sample was prepared under the same conditions in the absence of formamide and named as HT-W. 2.4 Synthesis of supported PtIn bimetallic catalysts The supported HT precursors were calcined at 600 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1 and then the calcined HT (namely HTC) supported PtIn catalysts were synthesized via the stepwise incipient wetness impregnation method as described below: Firstly, the calcined HT samples were impregnated in In(NO3)3·xH2O aqueous solution for 6 h at room temperature and followed by drying at 120 °C for 12 h and calcining at 550 °C for 4 h. Subsequently, the obtained In-based samples were used to introduce the Pt species by using H2PtCl6·H2O aqueous solution as impregnation liquid under the same procedure except for cutting the impregnation time to 2 h. The obtained solids were defined as PtIn/HTC-U and PtIn/HTC-W with Pt of 0.5 wt% and In of 1.4 wt%, respectively. As another comparison sample, the Al-rod supported PtIn catalyst, namely PtIn/C-Al-rod, was also prepared by the same method. Before dehydrogenation reaction, these calcined catalysts should be reduced in 5 vol% H2/N2 (30 mL min−1) at 600 °C for 2 h with a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1. The corresponding reduced catalysts were labeled as PtIn/HTR-U, PtIn/HTR-W and PtIn/R-Al-rod. After reaction, the spent catalysts were marked as PtIn/HTU-U, PtIn/HTU-W and PtIn/U-Al-rod. 2.5 Characterization of catalysts and precursors X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured with a Bruker D8-Focus X-ray diffractometer by means of Cu Kα (λ = 0.15418 nm) radiation at 40 kV and 200 mA with a scan speed of 8 ° min−1. Low temperature N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were performed on a Norcross TriStar 3000 micromeritics apparatus at −196 °C to characterize the textural properties of samples. Before the measurement, the solids were out-gassed at 300 °C for 4 h. The specific surface area was calculated based on BET equation, while the pore size distribution and pore volume were obtained by using BJH method based on the desorption branch of isotherm. The thickness of samples was collected by a Bruker Multimode 8 atomic force microscopy (AFM). Firstly, a small amount of powder was dispersed by ultrasonic in anhydrous ethanol. Then the suspension was dropped onto clean mica sheets and observed by AFM after drying. The AFM images were obtained by using chrome-plated/silicon tip with a force constant of 40 N m−1 in tap mode. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) test was carried on a Sp-5100 multifunctional adsorption instrument. The solid sample was firstly flushed with N2 at 400 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 100 °C, the gas was switched to 5 vol% H2/N2 with a flow rate of 30 mL min−1, and then the system was heated to 900 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1. At the same time, the H2 concentration was monitored by a TCD detector. NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was measured on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 apparatus. The sample was treated in He under a flow rate of 50 mL min−1 and heated from room temperature to 500 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1, then cooled to 100 °C for NH3 pulse adsorption until saturation. After He purging again for 1 h, the temperature was increased to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1, and the NH3 desorption signal was detected using a TCD detector. X-ray photo-electron spectra (XPS) of the reduced sample were determined on a PerkinElmer Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi apparatus with Al Kα radiation. All binding energy (BE) values were calibrated by using C1s signal of contaminant carbon at 284.8 eV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis of the reduced samples was verified on a JEM-2100F electron microscope at 200 kV. After ultrasonic dispersion of the reduced sample in anhydrous ethanol, the suspension was dropped on the copper grid and tested after drying. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained on a JEM-ARM 200F electron microscope capable. The ultra-thin carbon film on copper mesh was used to support and disperse the powder samples. The mapping images of Pt and In element were collected by using HAADF-STEM combined with energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) system. The Pt dispersion of the reduced sample was measured by CO adsorption on an AutoChem1 II 2920 chemoradiometer. The CO pulse adsorption was performed at 50 °C in the gas flow of 5 vol% CO/He until saturation. Assuming the CO/Pt adsorption stoichiometry ratio is 1, the Pt dispersion is calculated based on the CO chemisorption volume. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) of the spent catalyst was performed in air on a PerkinElmer DTG-50/50H apparatus. The mass loss was conducted from room temperature to 900 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1. 2.6 Dehydrogenation performance evaluation Before reaction, the calcined catalyst (0.5 g, 40–60 mesh) was reduced under the same condition described in Experimental section. The IDH behavior was conducted in a fixed-bed reactor with 3 h−1 of isobutane weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) at 600 °C and 0.1 MPa. The volumetric ratio of reactant isobutane and balance hydrogen was 1: 1, and the inlet and outlet gasses were monitored by a gas chromatography (GC) equipped with Al2O3 column and FID detector. The dehydrogenation performance of catalyst was evaluated by using isobutane conversion (C), isobutene selectivity (S) and yield (Y), and the formulas were given below: C = i C 4 H 10 , in − i C 4 H 10 , out i C 4 H 10 , in × 100 % S = i C 4 H 8 , out i C 4 H 10 , in − i C 4 H 10 , out × 100 % Y = C × S × 100 % where, iC4H10,in and iC4H10,out are the isobutane concentrations in inlet and outlet stream respectively, and iC4H8,out is the isobutene concentration in outlet stream. 2.7 Turnover frequency (TOF) calculation The diffusion - free operation was studied by changing the space velocity and particle size of catalyst. The results show that the external and internal diffusion effects can be safely excluded under the reaction conditions adopted in this paper. The TOF was determined according to the given formula: TOF ( s − 1 ) = F 22 . 4 × 60 × 1000 × C × M Pt m cat × ω Pt × D Pt where, F (mL·min−1), C (%), mcat (g), MPt (%), ωPt (%) and DPt (%) stand for the isobutane flow rate, isobutane conversion, catalyst mass, Pt molar mass, Pt loading amount and Pt dispersion, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic behaviors 3.1.1 Isobutane dehydrogenation performance In order to reveal the structural advantages of ultrathin HT nanosheets, the IDH activity and products selectivity over the derived catalysts PtIn/HTR-U, PtIn/HTR-W and PtIn/R-Al-rod were evaluated and the corresponding results are compared in Fig. 1 . Besides the target product isobutene, only one by-product methane can be monitored in the outlet gases, and the corresponding selectivity over these catalysts increases following the order: PtIn/HTR-U, PtIn/HTR-W and PtIn/R-Al-rod, but the methane selectivity is below 6% for PtIn/R-Al-rod and even ca. 2% for PtIn/HTR-U and PtIn/HTR-W. At the same time, the reactant isobutane conversion, main product isobutene selectivity and yield go an opposite trend. Another important difference is the stability among them. Obviously, PtIn/HTR-U possesses the optimal dehydrogenation activity and stability. Its isobutane conversion can be kept at ca. 63% and isobutene selectivity is still more than 92% within 6 h of reaction. Although the isobutene selectivity of PtIn/HTR-W can be maintained at 88%, the isobutane conversion declines from 64% to 57% with time on stream. However, the isobutane conversion and isobutene selectivity of PtIn/R-Al-rod drop dramatically from 50% to 36% and from 84% to 80%, respectively. From Fig. 1(b), it can be found that the isobutene yields of the three catalysts display a similar trend to the isobutane conversion. Although the yield of PtIn/HTR-U shows a slight fluctuation, but it still maintains above 58% throughout the reaction. At the same time, an obvious decrease yield can be found for PtIn/HTR-W from 57% to 51% and even a remarkable drop for PtIn/R-Al-rod from 42% to 29%. According to these results, it can be announced that the activity, selectivity and stability of PtIn/HTR-U are better than that of PtIn/HTR-W and even far better than PtIn/R-Al-rod. In addition, the negligible methane in gas-phase products hints that the hydrogenolysis reaction, which involving breakage of C-C bonds, can be efficiently inhibited by PtIn/HTR-U. The superior dehydrogenation performance of PtIn/HTR-U must be related to the special structure, texture feature, surface chemical state and physicochemical properties which will be revealed by comparing with PtIn/HTR-W in detail. 3.1.2 Carbon deposition behavior In order to study the deposited carbon behavior of PtIn/HTR-U and PtIn/HTR-W, the used catalyst PtIn/HTU-U and PtIn/HTU-W were characterized by TG technology and the curves drawn Fig. 2 . The mass loss of the used catalysts during the TG process is related to the removal of carbon deposition. It is obvious that the deposited carbon amount over PtIn/HTU-U is lower than that over PtIn/HTU-W. This indicates that PtIn/HTU-U has better anti-carbon deposition ability than PtIn/HTU-W, which must be related to the unique ultrathin nanosheet structure of PtIn/HTU-U. The low amount of deposited carbon, negligible methane by-product together with the stable and excellent catalytic performance over the catalyst derived from the ultrathin HT nanosheets suggest that the deposited carbon species tend to transfer from active Pt sites to support and the active Pt sintering can be effectively resisted [35]. All these can prolong the lifetime of the ultrathin catalyst in the IDH reaction. 3.2 Characteristics of catalysts 3.2.1 XRD The crystal phase structures of HT-U and HT-W precursor as well as support Al-Rod were indexed by XRD, and their patterns are displayed in Fig. 3 . HT-U and HT-W precursor shows two strong diffraction peaks at ca. 45.7° and 67°, it can be attributed to (400) and (440) plane characteristic diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS file No. 50-0741). In addition, a series of characteristic diffraction peaks for (003), (006), (012), (015) and (110) planes of HT phase appear at 2θ of 11.3°, 22.8°, 34.5°, 39.4° and 60.8° for HT-W. It indicates that the HT precursor can be in-situ assembled on the surface of Al-rod by sharing Al element. However, HT-U synthesized in formamide solution displays a weak (110) diffraction peak along with the disappearance of (003) diffraction peak, indicating the successful synthesis of ultrathin HT nanosheets [25]. The formation of ultrathin texture should be related to the stable adsorption of the lamellar growth inhibitor formamide on HT layer, which can inhibit the growth of HT microcrystal along the direction perpendicular to the HT layer and even prevent the stacking of the HT nanosheets [30,32]. As reported, the as-synthesized ultrathin HT nanosheets usually can be temporarily maintained in the wet state without drying treatment [36]. In this work, it is noteworthy that the drying treatment at 80 °C has not resulted in the stacking and repolymerization of ultrathin HT nanosheets. This should be related to the in-situ growth of ultrathin nanosheets on the surface of Al-rod, which making it possible for the nanosheets to be firmly anchored on Al-rod. The in situ formed HT derivatives were used to support active Pt and promoter In species and the phase compositions of the corresponding calcined and reduced samples were also investigated by XRD, which patterns are given in Fig. 4 . As shown in Fig. 4(a), all HT phase diffraction peaks have disappeared and the diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 phase still can be detected for the calcined samples. Furthermore, the new diffraction peaks at 2θ = 42.9°, 62.3° match well with (200) and (220) diffraction of MgO (JCPDF File No. 45-0946). It is necessary to emphasized that these diffraction peaks of MgO phase in PtIn/HTC-U are weaker than those in PtIn/HTC-W. This should be related to the poor crystalline of ultrathin HT nanosheets in HT-U. In other word, the evolution of MgO microcrystals is confined in the ultrathin nanosheets, therefore restraining the growth range of MgO microcrystals during thermal decomposition process. The absence of diffraction signals of Pt- and In-based species is another important information. It can be deduced that Pt and In species should be highly dispersed on the surface of support, resulting from the low concentration of metal species and the confinement effect of HT derivatives [5]. In Fig. 4(b), the XRD patterns of the reduced samples are shown to be similar to those of the calcined samples. Especially, the diffraction peaks of Pt- and In- related phases are still absent. These signify that the phase structure is stable enough for PtIn/HTR-U and PtIn/HTR-W during reduction at high temperature. This can be used to explain the better stability of PtIn/HTR-U and PtIn/HTR-W during dehydrogenation process. 3.2.2 AFM In order to further confirm the thickness of HT nanosheets, the AFM characterization are performed on the synthesized HT-U and HT-W. And the corresponding images and height analysis are presented in Fig. 5 . The results exhibit that the thickness of HT-W nanosheets synthesized in water is about 7.5 nm, while the value for HT-U nanosheets synthesized in formamide solution is only about 1.0 nm, which is almost equivalent to 0.8 nm of mono-layer HT nanosheets [31,32]. This indicates that the existence of formamide can exactly inhibit the growth of HT nanosheets along the direction perpendicular to the layer and help the formation of ultrathin structure. Additionally, the height images also demonstrate that the particle size of HT-U is more uniform than that of HT-W. 3.2.3 TEM and HAADF-STEM From Fig. 6 , the TEM image of PtIn/HTR-U clearly demonstrates that the Al-rods are tightly wrapped by many PtIn/HTR-U ultrathin nanosheets with uniform particle size, while the other image brings out that PtIn/HTR-W nanosheets are loosely deposited on the surface of Al-rods along with different particle size. But for each sample, the nanosheets are much small compared with some unsupported HT derivatives, as shown in references [9,10]. The open and short pore channels are beneficial to the diffusion of reactants and products [8]. In addition, it is difficult to determine the presence of metal particles on these TEM images, which is agreement with the XRD result mentioned above, indicating that the metal particles are too small to be identified [8]. This is attributed to the low concentration of metal species and the strong lattice confined effect of HT structure [5]. In order to determine the phase structure and size of metal particles, the HAADF-STEM images with particle size distribution of PtIn/HTR-U and PtIn/HTR-W and EDS mappings of PtIn/HTR-U are presented in Fig. 7 . From Fig. 7 (a and d), it can be seen that the dispersed bright spots are composed of many Pt atoms and there are no big Pt particles on the surface of support. This indicates that Pt clusters are the main chemical state of Pt species [5]. The EDS element maps of PtIn/HTR-U (Fig. 7c) further prove that Pt and In species are uniformly distributed on the support surface, arising from the lattice confinement effect of HT. Comparing the particle size distributions of PtIn/HTR-U and PtIn/HTR-W (Fig. 7 (b and e)), it can be seen that the average particle size of Pt clusters on PtIn/HTR-U is 1.29 nm, which is smaller than 1.55 nm of those on PtIn/HTR-W. It indicates that ultrathin nanosheets are more conducive to the dispersion of Pt particles. The activation of C-H bonds is a structurally sensitive behavior, therefore, the Pt clusters with smaller size would have lower dehydrogenation energy barriers and exhibit higher intrinsic activity [37,38]. It can be deduced that the formation small Pt clusters is the most important way for Pt-based catalysts to obtain superior dehydrogenation performance. 3.2.4 Texture feature The low temperature N2 adsorption - desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of calcined catalysts including PtIn/HTC-U and PtIn/HTC-W are given in Fig. 7. Some important parameters, involving specific surface area (S BET), pore volume (V p), and most probable pore size (D p) are analyzed and collected in Table 1 . As shown in Fig. 8 , the calcined catalysts PtIn/HTC-U and PtIn/HTC-W exhibit typical type IV adsorption isotherms, accompanied by type H3 hysteresis loop, indicating that the two catalysts possess mesoporous structures [8]. The formation of this hysteresis loop is related the existence of the slit pores built by the lamellar structure [39], which derived from the HT nanosheets in situ grown on the surface of Al-rods. In Table 1, the S BET, V p and D p values of these catalysts show an obvious increasing trend from PtIn/HTC-W to PtIn/HTC-U. The elevated textural data must be related to the ultrathin feature of PtIn/HTC-U, which topologically transformed from HT structure [22] and endowed with abundant pores. On the other hand, the pore size distribution range of PtIn/HTC-U is broader than that of PtIn/HTC-W. The hierarchical pore feature of PtIn/HTC-U also plays an important role in improving the activity and selectivity of isobutane dehydrogenation [39]. The large S BET and uniform pore size distribution of PtIn/HTC-U can optimize the distribution of Pt and In species, and thus obtain high isobutane dehydrogenation activity. At the same time, Pt dispersion (D pt) measured by CO pulse adsorption and turnover frequency (TOF) calculated by D pt are also listed in Table 1. It is worth noting that the D pt and TOF value of PtIn/HTC-U are nearly twice as high as that of PtIn/HTC-W. This indicates that the ultrathin nanosheets can effectively enhance the surface ratio of active Pt species and make the Pt centers can be fully utilized in the isobutane dehydrogenation. It is should be the direct reason of the excellent dehydrogenation performance for PtIn/HTR-U. The high TOF value of PtIn/HTC-U also means that it is possible for the formation and maintenance of surface single metal atom centers or metal atom clusters on the surface of ultrathin metal oxide nanosheets [38,40], which bearing out the HAADF-STEM deduction above. 3.2.5 H2-TPR The reduction properties of different catalysts and the interaction between metal components were studied based on the H2-TPR results as shown in Fig. 9 . Clearly, all catalysts are composed of a large and wide reduction peak, and there are three fitting peaks for both catalysts at ca. 300 °C (peak Ⅰ), 400 °C (peak Ⅱ) and 536 °C (peak Ⅲ), respectively. The semi-quantitative analysis of these peaks is conducted by deconvolution of Gaussian function fitting method, and the fitting data are summarized in Table 2 . According to the relevant reports [11], these peaks should be corresponded to the reduction of PtOx species at low temperature, InOx species interacting with PtOx and support at high temperature respectively. In Fig. 9, the reduction temperatures for peak Ⅰ and Ⅱ of PtIn/HTC-U are higher than those of PtIn/HTC-W, except the same peak Ⅲ temperatures. It indicates that the interaction among Pt, In and support is stronger in PtIn/HTC-U than that in PtIn/HTC-W. In other word, the effect of nanosheets thickness on the reducibility of catalysts is mainly arising from the different interaction strength among Pt, In and support. The strong interaction is just the reason of the stable dehydrogenation performance for PtIn/HTR-U. The data in Table 2 also show that the total peak area of PtIn/HTC-U is much larger than that of PtIn/HTC-W. This indicates that there are more reducible PtOx and InOx species in ultrathin sample than that in reference one. It demonstrates that the ultrathin nanosheets are beneficial to exposing and reducing PtOx and InOx species. At the same time, the peak II owns the largest area fraction in each sample, while the Peak III has the smallest value. This suggests that the Pt species could promote the reduction of partial InOx species. Compared with PtIn/HTC-W, the peak II area fraction of PtIn/HTC-U has a lower value. This hints that there is a lower amount of reductive In species on the surface of reduced PtIn/HTR-U. Additionally, the peak Ⅰ area fraction of PtIn/HTC-U is more than three times higher than that of PtIn/HTC-W. This predicts that there are more active metal Pt species on the reduced PtIn/HTR-U with ultrathin nanosheets, which is also consistent with the corresponding high Pt dispersion. Furthermore, the opposite trend for peak I and II also signifies that the surface Pt0/In0 ratio on PtIn/HTR-U would be higher than that on PtIn/HTR-W. In any case, the ultrathin nanosheet structure is beneficial to obtaining the more active metal Pt species by confinement reduction, while the strong interaction between In3+ ions and support can inhibit the reduction of In3+ ions, resulting in the more In3+ ions and less In0 species on PtIn/HTR-U than that on PtIn/HTR-W. 3.2.6 NH3-TPD As is known to all, the dehydrogenation performance of isobutane is also influenced by the surface acidity of catalysts. The acid sites distributions of the calcined PtIn/HTC-U and PtIn/HTC-W can be investigated by NH3-TPD measurement and the Gaussian function fitting method is used for deconvolution of the corresponding desorption peaks. The obtained curves are drawn in Fig. 10 and the fitting results are given in Table 3 . As shown in Fig. 10, there are four fitting peaks for the calcined PtIn/HTC-U and PtIn/HTC-W, which are peak Ⅰ located in the low temperature region, peak Ⅱ-Ⅲ located in the medium temperature region and peak Ⅳ located in the high temperature region, respectively. According to the reported results and analysis, they should be successively assigned to the weak-, medium- and strong-acid sites on the surface of calcined PtIn/HTC-U and PtIn/HTC-W. In Table 3, the total peak area of PtIn/HTC-U is slightly lower than that of PtIn/HTC-W. This indicates that the ultrathin nanosheets of PtIn/HTC-U can not only enhance the D pt value, but also boost the Mg utilization to neutralize partial surface acid sites. As we all known, the surface acid sites can activate isobutane dehydrogenation, but some undesired side reactions tend to occur at the strong-acid sites, thus affecting the isobutene selectivity [41]. As for peak Ⅰ, peak Ⅱ and peak Ⅲ, the maximal peak temperatures (TM) and peak area fraction of PtIn/HTC-U are higher than those of PtIn/HTC-W, while the contrary trend appears for peak Ⅳ. These mean that the strength and concentration of weak- and medium-acid sites on PtIn/HTC-U are higher than those on PtIn/HTC-W, but the acidity of strong-acid sites for PtIn/HTC-U is lower than that for PtIn/HTC-W. It can be confirmed that the strong medium-acid sites on PtIn/HTC-U make an important contribution to enhancing the isobutane conversion, and the weak strong-acid sites can effectively inhibit some side reactions, such as cracking and coking reactions [42], and thus result in the prominent isobutene selectivity and dehydrogenation stability for PtIn/HTC-U. 3.2.7 XPS Before dehydrogenation evaluation, the samples need to be reduced to obtain the appropriate chemical state and relative atom ratio of metal components on the reduced PtIn/HTR-U and PtIn/HTR-W, therefore the XPS analysis was carried out to obtain this information. It is necessary to account for the absence about the XPS spectra of Pt 4f region. It is the similar binding energies (BE) between Al 2p and Pt 4f make it difficult to distinguish Pt 4f spectra from Al 2p spectra [43]. Therefore, only the XPS spectra of In 3d region in the range of 440–460 eV are plotted in Fig. 11 . The broad In 3d peak has been deconvoluted into four peaks and the specific peak information of each sample is collected in Table 4 . This indicates that there are two In chemical states in the reduced catalysts. The peaks at low BE of 444.5 and 452.2 eV are attributed to the surface metal state In (In0), and the peaks at high BE of 445.6 and 453.2 eV depend on the oxidation state In (In3+) [9–11]. The BE values of In species in PtIn/HTR-U are slightly higher than those in PtIn/HTR-W, indicating that the formation of ultrathin nanosheets increases the interaction among In and other metal species as well as the electron transfer ability of In to Pt species [8]. This is in consistent with the above H2-TPR results (see Fig. 9). In addition, the In3+/In0 ratio of PtIn/HTR-U is much higher than that of PtIn/HTR-W. This suggests that the ultrathin nanosheets are more conducive to maintaining the ionic state of In3+, while the In3+ species in the ordinary HT derivative are easier to be reduced. Therefore, there are more metal In0 species on the surface of PtIn/HTR-W, which has been proved by the result of H2-TPR. According to the high D pt value and reduction temperature of PtIn/HTC-U mentioned above, it demonstrates that the high In3+/In0 ratio should be related to the easy surface segregation of active metal Pt0 species compared with the metal In0 species [44] and difficult reduction of In3+ species arising from the strong interaction among Pt, In and Al element in the ultrathin PtIn/HTR-U. The most important is that the existence of excess In0 species can block the Pt active sites [11,18], it should be one reason for the poor dehydrogenation performance over PtIn/HTR-W. Based on the results of HAADF-STEM, D pt and XPS, it can be deduced that an appropriate In3+/In0 ratio can not only avoid the coverage of Pt centers by In0 species, but also promote the dispersion and stability of Pt species by In0 insulation effect [11,18]. The difference about the surface chemical state and relative content of In species between PtIn/HTC-U and PtIn/HTC-W again reveals that the isobutane dehydrogenation performance can be improved by reducing the thickness of nanosheets to enhance the utilization and stabilization of supported active Pt species. 4 Conclusions In summary, we successfully in situ constructed stable ultrathin hydrotalcite nanosheets by using formamide as growth inhibitor on alumina support which providing the essential Al element. The excellent PtIn bimetallic catalysts can be obtained by combining stepwise incipient wetness impregnation method, calcination and reduction treatment, and successfully applied in the isobutane direct dehydrogenation at 600 °C. The XRD and AFM results verified the formation of ultrathin hydrotalcite nanosheets with a thickness of only 1.0 nm and no repolymerization occurred after high temperature treatment. Compared with PtIn/HTR-W with thick nanosheets, the ultrathin catalyst PtIn/HTR-U can obtain the optimal isobutane conversion (above 63%) and isobutene selectivity (above 92%) as well as excellent turnover frequency (13.45 s−1) and anti-carbon deposition behavior due to its large specific surface area, strong acidity of weak- and medium-acid sites, high In3+/In0 ratio and Pt dispersion (30%). The strong interaction among Pt, In and support, dispersion of appropriate In0 species and low carbon deposition further resulted in the stable dehydrogenation performance of PtIn/HTR-U. The formation of ultrathin hydrotalcite structure effectively improved the utilization and dispersion of active Pt species. This work provides an ingenious method to synthesize uniformly distributed and well dispersed noble metal catalysts and realizes the application of ultrathin hydrotalcite derivatives in the harsh condition of thermal catalysis. coredata.dc:description: The stable and ultrathin hydrotalcite nanosheets with thickness of ca. 1.0 nm have been built on the surface of Al2O3 by sharing Al element and using layer growth inhibitor formamide. Based on the topological transformation characteristics of hydrotalcite and the structural memory effect of calcined product, the supported PtIn bimetallic catalyst was achieved by stepwise incipient wetness impregnation method followed by calcination and reduction, and evaluated in isobutane direct dehydrogenation (IDH) to isobutene. The derived ultrathin bimetallic catalyst possesses excellent IDH activity under extreme conditions, in which the isobutane conversion and isobutene selectivity can remain above 63% and 92% respectively, and the turnover frequency is as high as 13.45 s−1. The excellent activity can be attributed to the formation of ultrathin hydrotalcite precursor, which can greatly enhance the specific surface area, interaction among metal components, surface acidity of weak- and medium-acid sites and surface In3+/In0 ratio, and further effectively inhibit carbon deposition and improve dispersion and stability of active Pt species in the corresponding derivative.
coredata.dc:title: In-situ constructed ultrathin hydrotalcite derivative supported PtIn catalyst for isobutane direct dehydrogenation
